value: A horse farm in bluegrass country

's most famous region, if not its most visited. The coveted grass that suburban homeowners slave to get to grow on their lawns throughout the country grows naturally in this bucolic region on its native soil, and helps sustain the major local industry—Kentucky horse farms.

value: — known for its arts and crafts scene, and home to Berea College

Visitors have the option of flying directly into the smaller
, or flying into larger airports further away.
are both about 1.5 hours away from Lexington, but are served by more airlines than Blue Grass Airport.

Travellers can access the Bluegrass Region via one of the two major interstates that arc around the northern and eastern borders of the city. I-64 runs from east to west, connecting Lexington with the largest city in Kentucky, Louisville, to the west. I-75 runs north-south, connecting Lexington with Cincinnati and Knoxville respectively.  These interstates intersect just north of Lexington.
There are no passenger rail lines in the Bluegrass Region.
has routes that serve Eastern, Western, and Northern Kentucky as well as Cincinnati, and has bus service from Chicago to Loiusville.

value: , 477 W New Circle Rd NW, Lexington, KY 40511,

A car is a necessity to get around the area.  The Bluegrass region is a large area, with public transportation only existing in the largest towns in the region, and even then limited to busses and by-appointment-only taxis.

value: address=625 William Whitley Rd. Stanford, KY 40484

content=The William Whitley House is one of the first brick homes west of the Allegheny Mountains and is site of the first circular racetrack in Kentucky. It was completed in 1794 by William Whitley and his wife Esther

Drive to Harrodsburg and Danville, 32 miles southwest of Lexington, to see some of the oldest buildings in the State.  Take Versailles Road, out of Lexington, then take the Bluegrass Parkway to US-127, to Harrodsburg.  This path will take you by the
, and through Central Kentucky's scenic farmland.

value: Harrodsburg is Kentucky's oldest city and contains a reconstruction of
, the first permanent settlement in the state of Kentucky. Re-enactors are present on a seasonal basis.
http://www.shakervillageky.org/ Shaker Village of Pleasant Hill

is America’s largest restored Shaker community, with 34 carefully restored buildings and 3,000 acres of preserved farmland.  Shaker Village features a restaurant and lodging onsite, guided tours, and seasonal activities and re-enactors.

contains recreations of buildings from the 1700s and was the site where Kentucky's first Constitution was signed.  The buildings are open year round for self-guided viewing, and guided tours are available by appointment.

From Danville, Lexington Road will connect you with US-27, which will return you to Lexington.
The Bluegrass Region is home to many small towns, each with their own reason to visit.

value: , 35 miles southwest of Lexington,  is the "City of Firsts", and the "Birthplace of the Bluegrass" since the first Constitutional Convention in the West was held at Constitution Square in 1792 and Kentucky's first Constitution was signed there.
, Kentucky's capital city, is 25 miles northwest of Lexington.
is a quaint and colorful railroad town halfway between Lexington and Frankfort; stop for a bite to eat and explore the antique and boutique shops downtown.
, 32 miles southwest of Lexington, is Kentucky's oldest city.
, 30 miles southwest of Lexington, is America’s largest restored Shaker community, with 34 carefully restored buildings and 3,000 acres of preserved farmland.
, 60 miles from Lexington, is Kentucky's second oldest city.

, 37 miles south of the city, is a major center for folk arts & crafts. Old Town has many working artists studios, and the Kentucky Artisan Center, just off I-75, serves as a visitors' center and showcases the wares of many regional artisans.

Kentucky cuisine to look for includes the Hot Brown, an open-faced sandwich of turkey, bacon, and cheese sauce; burgoo, a traditional game stew with as many variations as there are people who make it; beer cheese, a spicy spread of cheddar cheese and beer; and bourbon balls, a chocolate and bourbon truffle with pecans.
 
Note that smoking is banned in restaurants, bars, and many public buildings.

is home to an astonishing number of independently owned restaurants at all price levels. The city's college town atmosphere and affluent lifestyle contribute to this relatively small metropolitan area's great culinary offerings. Chain restaurants, typical in most American cities and towns, can be found here, as well as a great number of privately owned and operated establishments. Lexington has an amazing variety of regional and ethnic foods. Almost any taste can be fulfilled, from Home Cookin' to Fine Dining and from Cajun to Vietnamese.
has a wide variety of restaurants to choose from while visiting.

content=Wallace Station is a hidden local favorite, known for huge, delicious sandwiches and wonderful desserts.  A small place with a real country feel.

content=Although it's well outside Lexington (it's halfway to Richmond), the easy scenic drive down KY-418 and location on the Kentucky River make it worthwhile. Try their famous beer cheese for an appetizer, and enjoy their excellent seafood selection, or play it safe with the very large "Kentucke River" Hot Brown.
name=The Inn at Shaker Village at Pleasant Hill
content=A mix of traditional southern and continental foods, served at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.  Call ahead to ensure available seating.

have their own smaller bar scenes.

are plentiful in the area, due to the particular geology of the region that make this distinctively Kentuckian liquor possible. Many distilleries operate tours where you can learn about the processes of mashing, distilling, and aging, and often sample the product. Traveling between the distilleries is called "Taking the
." Souvenir T-Shirts and Bourbon Trail "passports" are available. Each distillery has their own souvenirs available for purchase, ranging from shot glasses to

.

Five distilleries are within 30 miles of Lexington.

Many Kentucky Wineries produce award winning wine.  The winery business is growing, with several new vineyards starting up in the Bluegrass Region.

, 79 miles west, is Kentucky's largest city and is famous for—among other things—the Kentucky Derby and the Louisville Slugger Museum.

, 120 miles south, has some of the most beautiful scenery and breathtaking rock formations in the state.  Kentuckians visit the area during all seasons to enjoy camping, rock climbing, hiking, and watersports.
is centered around Kentucky's Mammoth Cave, the worlds longest continuous cave system.  Visitors can go on many tours of the cave system, with varying degrees of difficulty.
